author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Unrest in France Eases Nearly a Week After Fatal Police Shooting
description: The number of arrests fell sharply following several nights of violence. But tensions remain high, especially after a string of attacks on elected officials.
content: The violent protests and unrest that spread across France after the fatal police shooting of a teenager last week diminished significantly overnight, the authorities said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israel Launched Attacks on the West Bank
description: Also, our Fourth of July recipes. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Early this morning, Israeli drones fired on a densely populated refugee camp in the West Bank and hundreds of Israeli troops were sent into the area’s narrow streets and alleys. The military said the goal of the assault, the biggest in nearly two decades, was to root out armed militants after a year of escalating violence there. At least eight Palestinians were reported to have been killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Anthony Bouza, Police Commander Who Ruffled Feathers, Dies at 94
description: A self-confessed maverick, he was praised by some and criticized by others for ideas that upset the law-enforcement status quo.
content: Anthony V. Bouza, who as a police commander in New York City earned both praise and criticism for his emphasis on research and his often blunt remarks about policing, and who later introduced pioneering anti-crime tactics as the police chief of Minneapolis, died on June 26 in Bloomington, Minn. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: Texas Barbecue Is the Best It Has Ever Been. Here’s Why.
description: In a new golden age, younger pitmasters are advancing the form using dynamic flavors from Black, Mexican and Asian cuisines, among others.
content: Lockhart is the Barbecue Capital of Texas. This has been officially true since 1999 — thanks to a proclamation passed by the Texas House of Representatives — and unofficially true for years before that, thanks to how long people have been eating smoked meat in the Central Texas town. Three of Lockhart’s most famous barbecue joints have been open for a combined 289 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘The Idol’ Season Finale Recap: What Was the Point?
description: The season finale, like the rest of the series, had little of substance to say about either pop music or power dynamics.
content: “The Idol” has concluded its five-episode run, and there’s one question I can’t help but ask: What was the point of all of that?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Pro-Kennedy Super PAC Says It Has Raised $10 Million
description: A super PAC backing Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said an even mix of Republicans and Democrats contributed to its $10.25 million haul.
content: A political action committee supporting Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s presidential campaign has raised a total of $10.25 million, one of its leaders said on Monday, a signal that his long-shot challenge to President Biden has gained traction among donors, including many Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Will America Be Ready for Its 250th Birthday?
description: History is a partisan battleground. A troubled national planning commission is attempting a reboot. Here comes the Semiquincentennial, ready or not.
content: For those planning the United States’ Semiquincentennial in 2026, the past few years have sometimes felt like one long winter at Valley Forge.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 3, 2023
description: No corrections that appeared in print on Monday, July 3, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Thomas
title: Can Couture Be More Socially Responsible?
description: Renaissance, a French nonprofit, focuses on producing upcycled pieces made in the couture style while providing job training opportunities.
content: On a cold evening in March, a cement-floored warehouse in the gritty Paris suburb of Fontenay-sous-Bois played host to a different kind of couture fashion show. A model in a short-sleeved jacket with a bronze chevron bodice, navy silk chiffon kilt and swinging bronze chain fringe marched out to a D.J.’s club beat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Can Biden Change the Economic Narrative?
description: The numbers have greatly improved. Will voters give him credit?
content: Back in the 1970s, Arthur Okun, an economist who had been a policy adviser to Lyndon Johnson, suggested a quick-and-dirty way to assess the nation’s economic condition: the “misery index,” the sum of inflation and unemployment. It was and is a crude, easily criticized measure. The measurable economic harm from unemployment, for instance, is much higher than that from inflation. Yet the index has historically done a quite good job of predicting overall economic sentiment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel Launches Biggest Air Attack on West Bank in Nearly Two Decades
description: Israel said it used drone-fired missiles and ground troops against militant targets in the Jenin refugee camp. The assault killed at least eight Palestinians, the Palestinian health ministry said.
content: Israel launched its most intense airstrikes on the occupied West Bank in nearly two decades on Monday, and sent hundreds of ground troops into the narrow streets and alleys of the crowded Jenin refugee camp, saying it was trying to root out armed militants after a year of escalating violence there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Prigozhin’s public support remains significant despite Russian propaganda efforts, polls show.
description: Experts are divided over the accuracy of polling in Russia, but polling firms say well-designed surveys can still produce reliable results.
content: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin’s failed rebellion sharply dented his domestic support, but nearly 30 percent of Russians continue to view the Wagner mercenary leader positively, according to opinion polls whose results were released Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: At UChicago, a Debate Over Free Speech and Cyber Bullying
description: A student objected to a class, “The Problem of Whiteness,” and tweeted the lecturer’s photo and email address. Hate mail poured in. What should the school do?
content: Rebecca Journey, a lecturer at the University of Chicago, thought little of calling her new undergraduate seminar “The Problem of Whiteness.” Though provocatively titled, the anthropology course covered familiar academic territory: how the racial category “white” has changed over time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: There Won’t Be Much New York in Seattle at This Year’s All-Star Game
description: Gerrit Cole and Aaron Judge of the Yankees made the A.L. squad, and Pete Alonso of the Mets will represent the N.L. Last year, the teams combined for 10 selections.
content: The Mets and the Yankees have the two largest payrolls in Major League Baseball, with more than $600 million in combined player salaries, according to Spotrac. Luxury tax bills, which will be finalized later this year, will push the combined number well over $700 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: Frederick Douglass Knew What False Patriotism Was
description: Frederick Douglass expanded the meaning of American patriotism by reminding the nation what it still owed its populace.
content: In 1852 Frederick Douglass delivered what may be his most famous address, “What to the Slave Is the Fourth of July?” This time of year, quotations from the speech dart around Black social media as a subtle pushback on uncomplicated celebrations of American independence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: When Missiles Strike Kyiv, These Psychologists Race to Help
description: Emergency responders in Ukraine’s capital offer not only physical care to the victims of airstrikes, but also mental health support for survivors in crisis.
content: Hands shaking as she covered her mouth, a woman looked toward a gaping hole in the side of a high-rise, the contents of apartments spilling out of its side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Rachel Quester, Alex Stern, Shannon Lin, Michael Simon Johnson, Marc Georges, Paige Cowett, Devon Taylor, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: A Clash Between Religious Faith and Gay Rights
description: A recent Supreme Court ruling put freedom of expression above freedom from discrimination.
content: The Supreme Court delivered another major decision this past week, ruling in favor of a web designer who said she had a First Amendment right to refuse to create wedding websites for same-sex couples.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: In Tuna-Obsessed Tunisia, a Favorite Food Becomes a Lot Less Affordable
description: Tunisians put canned tuna on pizza, pastries and pretty much everything else. Don’t even ask for a tuna-free sandwich. But inflation risks turning an everyday essential into a luxury out of reach.
content: Perhaps you are one of the more than 5,000 subscribers to “Popping Tins,” an email newsletter devoted exclusively to tinned seafood. Perhaps you belong to a tinned-fish-of-the-month club, or have leafed through a tinned-fish-focused cookbook that tells you how best to cook a food already cooked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: She’s Going Into 6th Grade and Already Saving for College
description: A New York City program encourages children to save from kindergarten.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today, two education-related topics. We’ll meet a rising middle schooler whose focus is on saving for college. And we’ll look at what the decision on affirmative action might mean for students who don’t attend schools with race-conscious admissions policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Judge Investigated Over His Profane TikTok Videos
description: The New Jersey judge, Gary Wilcox, posted the videos using an alias. In some, he wore judicial robes. At least one was recorded from bed.
content: For two years, a judge in New Jersey used a pseudonym to post TikTok videos of himself lip-syncing lyrics from popular rap songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: The Supreme Court’s Blockbuster Rulings, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Tell Me There Isn’t a Witch Hunt in Tennessee
description: We live in two countries now: one where basic civil and human rights are recognized and another where ideological extremists can decide how everyone else lives.
content: NASHVILLE — Two weeks ago, while the rest of America was absorbed by the hunt for a doomed submersible, people in Tennessee discovered that their attorney general was conducting a witch hunt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: An Opera Partnership’s Next Step: A Fable About Happiness
description: George Benjamin and Martin Crimp, who collaborated on modern successes including “Written on Skin,” return with the one-act “Picture a Day Like This.”
content: In one scene of George Benjamin’s new opera “Picture a Day Like This,” which premieres on Wednesday at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France, a composer and her assistant cut off an interviewer midsentence. The composer asks whether there’s space in her schedule to speak; “five minutes,” the assistant replies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Russia’s Embassy in Washington Becomes a Different Kind of Battle Zone
description: The compound has turned into the scene of protests, spy games and general weirdness as the most hostile relations in decades play out between the United States and Russia.
content: On a warm June night, Benjamin Wittes was seated at a card table across the street from the Russian Embassy in Washington, kicking off his light show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Senegal’s President Rules Out a Divisive Third Term
description: Macky Sall had considered seeking a third term in the West African country despite a constitutional limit of two.
content: President Macky Sall of Senegal said on Monday that he would not seek a third term in office, putting an end to months of tensions over a hypothetical candidacy that many say would have violated the West African nation’s Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: SPAC Tied to Trump’s Media Business Says It Has a Deal With Regulators
description: Digital World’s settlement with the S.E.C. could clear the way for a merger with Trump Media & Technology Group.
content: The cash-rich special purpose acquisition company that has a pending deal with former President Donald J. Trump’s media business announced on Monday that it had reached a tentative settlement with securities regulators over an investigation that had stymied the merger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By  Joann Plockova
title: As Cases Soar, ‘Dementia Villages’ Look Like the Future of Home Care
description: A new generation of treatment facilities is aiming to integrate dementia patients with the communities around them, blurring lines between home and hospital.
content: On a recent morning in this quiet village outside Amsterdam, an older woman stocked shelves inside the local supermarket. In the plaza just outside the store, a group of men sat around a table, chatting the hours away. Over in the town square, a woman in a hijab sipped coffee outside the cafe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: At Wimbledon, Novak Djokovic Aims to Clean Up on the Grass
description: If Djokovic can win his fifth consecutive title at the All England Club, he will be three-quarters of the way to a Grand Slam.
content: Novak Djokovic, bent over with a towel in hand, delighted the Centre Court crowd during a rain delay at Wimbledon on Monday when he mopped some moisture from the grass. It seemed appropriate for someone who has been doing the same general thing to his opponents over the last five years at this tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: The Secret to an Excellent Sandwich
description: In search of the perfect, flavor-layered bite, sandwich shops are focusing on restraint, approaching every element with a high level of care.
content: Carefully considered and seasoned, each layer of the Surfer, a turkey sandwich Matt Cahn serves at his Middle Child in the heart of Philadelphia, locks into place. The melty Swiss cheese, the spiced blueberry chutney, the vinaigrette-dressed arugula and the housemade deli turkey sit atop a thick smear of Duke’s mayonnaise inside a toasted ciabatta roll. The sandwich has nary a dry bit, and the precision of flavors is illuminating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: A Baltimore Party, a Hail of Gunfire and a Neighborhood Shattered
description: The shooting on Sunday in the city’s Brooklyn neighborhood killed two people and wounded 28 others.
content: In videos from a block party on Saturday night, hundreds of teenagers and young adults are seen dancing in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Baltimore and singing along to the lyrics of local rappers. As they shout and move their hands through the air, many hold up phones to record the revelry on a hot summer night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.9 Million Homes in California
description: A 1929 Spanish-style house in Glendale, an Edwardian home in San Francisco and a midcentury ranch house in Solana Beach.
content: This house is in Royal Canyon, a historic district with many Spanish and Mediterranean Revival homes built in the 1920s and an active neighborhood association that holds events throughout the year. It is about a mile from Verdugo Woodlands Elementary School, a well-ranked public school for students in kindergarten through sixth grade. The property is also close to Verdugo Park, which has open space for picnics and fields for soccer and baseball, and to The Americana at Brand, an outdoor shopping mall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: disdainful
description: This word has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word disdainful has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 27 in the book review “My Father the Frustrated Artist” by Christopher Sorrentino:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Byerly
title: The Ultramarathoner Racing Against the Course, and Himself
description: Nickademus de la Rosa, an ultrarunning prodigy who has run across Death Valley and the Alps, is taking a pause from the sport as he copes with borderline personality disorder.
content: Trudging up a brier-covered mountain in freezing temperatures with a dying headlamp, Nickademus de la Rosa knew his attempt to finish the Barkley Marathons, a 100-plus-mile race in Tennessee, was coming to an end, as it eventually would for most other entrants. The race has no trail markers, an elevation gain comparable to climbing Everest twice from sea level and a finish rate that hovers around 1 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of June 26, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Do Yoga Pants Qualify as Real Pants?
description: A reader is searching for comfortable, stretchy pants that can be worn for more than sun salutations.
content: Yoga pants — that is to say, leggings but with a higher waist and made from thicker material than actual leggings (sometimes, though not necessarily, with a bit of flare at the ankle) — are garments that, especially during pandemic lockdowns, became something of a joy to wear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Cricket Dispute Has Australia Leading and England Crying Foul
description: A play at the Ashes was technically called correctly, yet it had England’s fans chanting, “Same old Aussies, always cheating.” Even Britain’s prime minister has weighed in.
content: It just wasn’t cricket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: With Indiana Jones’s Return, Looking Back at the Opening Scene of ‘Raiders’
description: A shot-by-shot breakdown of the “Raiders of the Lost Ark” sequence that became a defining one in adventure movies.
content: “Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny” (now in theaters) is the first film in that franchise not directed by Steven Spielberg, who developed the character all those years ago with George Lucas and Philip Kaufman, as well as the screenwriter Lawrence Kasdan. Yet the handoff of directorial duties to James Mangold doesn’t feel like a strain, because Spielberg established the character of the globe-trotting archaeologist and the style of his cinematic escapades so adroitly over the first four films.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Churchill Downs Extends the Suspension of Bob Baffert Through 2024
description: Baffert, a Hall of Fame trainer, was suspended after his horse Medina Spirit failed a drug test at the 2021 Kentucky Derby. Churchill Downs said he “continues to peddle a false narrative” about what happened.
content: Churchill Downs on Monday extended its suspension of the trainer Bob Baffert from the Kentucky Derby through 2024, asserting his continued unwillingness to accept responsibility for the failed post-race drug test of Medina Spirit, the 2021 Derby winner, demonstrates that Baffert “cannot be trusted to avoid future misconduct.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Adrienne’s, Serving Tastes of Southern Italy, Opens in the Rockaways
description: A Milan-inspired cafe comes to NoMad, Dan Kluger opens a bakery in Hudson Yards and more restaurant news.
content: Adrienne Guttieri, a promising young chef who studied in Italy and worked her way up at restaurants there and in New York, died last summer at 33. Her family, most notably her brother, Frank Guttieri, is keeping her memory and legacy alive at this new restaurant named for her in their hometown area of the Rockaways. They have taken over the waterfront Bayview Restaurant, which has been dark for some time, and turned it into this taste of Southern Italy. A cousin, Chris Keegan, is the manager. There’s seating on a deck overlooking Jamaica Bay and boat slips, and indoors there are leather banquettes. The executive chef, Jeff Haskell, was Ms. Guttieri’s mentor at Trademark Bar+ Kitchen, in Midtown. Assorted raw bar items, lobster arancini, rigatoni Bolognese, spaghetti with clams and enhancements like preserved lemons and ’nduja butter, farrotto with asparagus and peas, roast chicken and veal chop Milanese are on the menu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Harvard’s Admissions Is Challenged for Favoring Children of Alumni
description: After the Supreme Court banned race-conscious affirmative action, activists filed a complaint, saying legacy admissions helped students who are overwhelmingly rich and white.
content: It’s been called affirmative action for the rich: Harvard’s special admissions treatment for students whose parents are alumni, or whose relatives donated money. And in a complaint filed on Monday, a legal activist group demanded that the federal government put an end to it, arguing that fairness was even more imperative after the Supreme Court last week severely limited race-conscious admissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: It’s Not America’s Unhappiest Birthday
description: How much pessimism about the future of the United States is warranted?
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, happy almost Independence Day. In the spirit of the holiday: Is America toast?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriela Sá Pessoa and Edward Wong
title: The U.S. ambassador to Russia meets with detained WSJ reporter.
description: Evan Gershkovich has been held at Moscow’s notorious Lefortovo Prison since late March on accusations of espionage that the United States and his employer vehemently reject.
content: The U.S. ambassador to Russia, Lynne M. Tracy, met with the detained Wall Street Journal correspondent Evan Gershkovich at Lefortovo Prison in Moscow on Monday, according to the State Department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: Chicago-Style Hot Dogs and Hawaii-Style Sherbet for Your Fourth of July
description: With chile-spiked cucumbers, watermelon chaat and perfect s’mores.
content: Hello, readers! Julia Moskin here, filling in for Melissa Clark. Kim Severson and I will be covering for her this week and next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Hot New Italian Player at Wimbledon: Gucci
description: Jannik Sinner swapped his athletic bag for a large logo-covered duffel by Gucci. It may be a new frontier for luxury brands in tennis.
content: It was the kind of bag you may spot in the overhead bin of an airplane’s first-class cabin. Except it was being carried onto Centre Court at Wimbledon by a 6-foot-2-inch redhead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: In Moving Images, Michael Snow Teases the Eye and the Mind
description: A retrospective for the artist at The School in Kinderhook, N.Y., showed how he worked across mediums and genres — painting, sculpture, film and music.
content: Our attention spans have shrunk over the last half century. Consider Michael Snow’s “Wavelength” (1967), a rigorous 45-minute film made by the Canadian artist that stands as a monument of experimental cinema. Snow understood what he was up against: In 2003 he made a video called “WVLNT: WAVELENGTH for Those Who Don’t Have the Time: Originally 45 Minutes, Now 15!” It wasn’t merely a joke or a concession. Knowing that people were choosing to watch his film digitally sped-up, Snow used the occasion to create a brand-new work, superimposing 15-minute segments of the original onto one another like gauzy layers of celluloid film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson and Priya Krishna
title: The 20 Best Texas Barbecue Restaurants From the New Generation
description: Over the last decade, the rule book for barbecue has been rewritten. Here are some the most important new authors of this singular cuisine.
content: A renaissance in Texas barbecue has transformed what was once a hidebound tradition into one of the country’s most dynamic vernacular cuisines, changing the landscape of American barbecue in the process — and turning Texas into the country’s ultimate barbecue destination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Krolik, Paul Mozur and Adam Satariano
title: Cracking Down on Dissent, Russia Seeds a Surveillance Supply Chain
description: Russia is incubating a cottage industry of new digital surveillance tools to suppress domestic opposition to the war in Ukraine. The tech may also be sold overseas.
content: As the war in Ukraine unfolded last year, Russia’s best digital spies turned to new tools to fight an enemy on another front: those inside its own borders who opposed the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Henderson
title: The Days Were Long and the Years Were Longer
description: In her new memoir, “The Light Room,” Kate Zambreno looks back on the unending togetherness of family life during the pandemic.
content: We find ourselves in the age of Covid literature. The publishing cycle, notoriously long, has caught up with the pandemic, and a book on the subject no longer seems like a novelty. But like the pandemic itself, the genre is still slippery. Are we at its height? Will it come back, in some new variant? How scared should we be?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Ignoring the Red Flags for the Thrill
description: “The Idol” was bad, but it did get one thing right: Sometimes we pick people we know we shouldn’t.
content: This article contains spoilers for the first season of “The Idol.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Number of Migrants Crossing U.S. Southern Border Is Down. But for How Long?
description: Officials say the lull after nearly two years of increased crossings is not going to last.
content: Nearly two months since the lifting of a public health order that allowed the United States to swiftly expel migrants at the southern border, the number of migrants crossing into the country has not only sharply declined, but has also remained relatively low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Simmering tensions in France.
content: Last week, a teenage boy was killed in a fatal traffic stop outside Paris, prompting days of violent protests. Days later, France’s top administrative court upheld a ban on religious symbols that has prevented a French citizen who wears a hijab from playing soccer. The cases are different, but each touches upon deep-seated issues of identity and inclusion in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Paul Justman, Who Shed Light on Motown’s Unsung Heroes, Dies at 74
description: After establishing himself as a leading music video director in the 1980s, he found acclaim with his 2002 documentary about session musicians.
content: During the filming of a climactic scene in his critically acclaimed documentary, “Standing in the Shadows of Motown,” a celebration of the unheralded session musicians behind countless 1960s hits, Paul Justman could have found himself foiled by Detroit’s harsh winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: What to Know About a Seemingly Fake Document in a Gay Rights Case
description: A supposed request for a website for a same-sex wedding played a minor role in a major clash between free speech and gay rights at the Supreme Court.
content: After the Supreme Court ruled last week that a Colorado graphic designer has the right to refuse to create websites for same-sex marriages, critics of the decision raised questions about a form included in court papers in the case that appeared to show that a gay couple had sought the services of the designer, Lorie Smith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Shesol
title: The Tragedy of John Roberts
description: The term that just ended must have been a torment for the chief justice. But his behavior has only made matters worse.
content: In June 2012, at the end of a contentious Supreme Court term that decided, among other things, the fate of the Affordable Care Act, Chief Justice John Roberts prepared to leave for Malta, to teach a course on the court. “Malta, as you know, is an impregnable island fortress,” he joked on the eve of his trip. “It seemed like a good idea.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: With DeSantis on the Stump, Disney Sees a Long Campaign Ahead
description: The company, long allergic to controversy, is likely to be the subject of very public and partisan criticism throughout the Republican primary.
content: As Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has embarked on his presidential run, a main pillar of his message is “holding woke corporations accountable,” as a fund-raising email put it on Tuesday. And to hammer home that sentiment, he has been railing against one target at nearly every campaign stop: Disney.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Supreme Court’s Ruling on Refusing Gay Business
description: Readers criticize the ruling and worry about “a slippery slope.” Also: Care, not jail, for drug users; your Wordle scores.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: 4.6-Magnitude Earthquake Shakes Alaska
description: More than 1,000 people reported feeling the earthquake, which struck northeast of Anchorage. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries, the authorities said.
content: A 4.6-magnitude earthquake rumbled through an area northeast of Anchorage on Monday morning, the United States Geological Survey said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Sundaes Best Serves Ube Gelato and More Korean Flavors
description: Visit the Koreatown shop from Joseph Ko and Bobby Kwak, enjoy a family barbecue sauce from a grandmother and more food news.
content: A scoop of dark chocolate, gianduja or coffee is what you might expect at a typical gelateria almost anywhere in the world. At the bright new Sundaes Best gelateria, in Manhattan’s Koreatown, you’ll also find ube, kalamansi, and injeolmi (mochi Korean rice cake). Bobby Kwak, the restaurateur best known for Baekjeong Korean Barbecue, and Joseph Ko, a partner in that restaurant company, opened the shop after Mr. Ko spent time in California learning how to make gelato and acquiring the needed equipment. Mr. Ko worked with the chef Michael Sim, another partner, in developing the recipes. They thought the lower butterfat and sugar in gelato would be compatible with some Asian taste preferences. Cups and cones start at $6.95 for two scoops. There are mochi doughnuts for $3.25. Oh, and they do not compose sundaes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Keith Bradsher
title: Yellen to Visit China in Bid to Steady Economic Ties
description: The trip to Beijing will be her first as Treasury secretary and is intended to ease tensions between the world’s two largest economies.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen will travel to China this week, a high-stakes visit that is intended to help stabilize the fraught relationship between the world’s two largest economies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lesley M. M. Blume
title: How Stalin’s Control of Foreign Reporters Helped Shape Russia Coverage Today
description: In “The Red Hotel,” Alan Philps, a former Moscow correspondent, documents the lives of Western journalists under Stalin and traces through lines to media relations in Russia today.
content: In the early years of World War II, Godfrey Blunden, an ambitious Australian correspondent for The Sydney Daily Telegraph, was hardly a household name. But in the winter of 1943, Blunden, then a Moscow-based reporter, suddenly came out with one blockbuster wartime story after another. Taken by Soviet press handlers to front lines first in Russia and then Ukraine, he revealed Nazi atrocities in Kharkiv. The Germans, he reported, had slaughtered 15,000 Jewish civilians — some of whom had been made to dig their own graves first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Why Do Mosquitoes Like Me So Much?
description: There are two main factors at play.
content: Q: I get bitten by mosquitoes way more often than my friends and family. Why is that? And is there anything I can do to make it stop?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Picard
title: Giving New York a Try, and Leaving the Big Stuff to Fate
description: A woman from Sydney wondered how long she could last in New York. Five years later, she’s really beginning to feel at home.
content: Adriana Stefanatos didn’t know how long she’d stay in New York — Three weeks? Three months? — when she moved from Australia. Five years later, she feels like she’s finally made it her own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: Ukrainian Nuclear Plant Is Just One of Innumerable Problems for Its Neighbors
description: Ukrainians who live near the Russian-occupied Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant have grown largely complacent about the dangers despite warnings that the facility has a bull’s-eye on it.
content: Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, keeps warning of an impending nuclear tragedy. His military intelligence chief, Kyrylo Budanov, recently said the Russians have “drafted and approved” a plan to sabotage the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, Europe’s biggest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Quinn Moreland
title: How Julie Byrne’s Astral Folk Music Took Flight
description: After the loss of her closest collaborator, the singer-songwriter paused but didn’t retreat. “The Greater Wings,” the follow-up to her 2017 breakthrough, is due Friday.
content: “I’m not trying to be eccentric, I promise!” Julie Byrne joked as she carefully arranged colorful tiles and bits of clay on the dining room table of her minimally furnished Queens apartment. The singer-songwriter, cozily stylish in a milk chocolate-colored tank top, cargo pants and snug knit slippers, located a pair of jagged white tiles that bore a phrase scribbled in black Sharpie: “Letting go.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: A New Kind of Disaster Aid: Pay People Cash, Before Disaster Strikes
description: Experiments suggest that sums as low as $50 can help the world’s poorest protect themselves and their property in ways they couldn’t otherwise.
content: Disasters can push the world’s poorest deeper into poverty. Now aid agencies are trying something new. They’re giving small bits of cash to people just before disaster strikes, instead of waiting until afterward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Ulrich
title: Why Car Repairs Have Become So Expensive
description: More technology and creature comforts, as well as a parade of new electric vehicles, have complicated the job after accidents.
content: New cars and trucks are packed with sensors and technology that protect and pamper drivers and passengers. But those features are also raising the cost of repairs after accidents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Rubin
title: Peter Brötzmann, 82, Dies; His Thunderous Saxophone Shook Jazz Traditions
description: One of Europe’s most influential free-jazz musicians, he played with “a kind of scream” to exorcise his demons, and those of German history.
content: Peter Brötzmann, an avant-garde saxophonist whose ferocious playing and uncompromising independence made him one of Europe’s most influential free-jazz musicians, died on June 22 at his home in Wuppertal, Germany. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Raúl Vilchis
title: New Migrants Have a Year to Apply for Asylum. Many Won’t Make It.
description: Tens of thousands of people who crossed the border in the last year planned to apply for asylum. But the complexities of the process mean many will fail.
content: Santos Lopez uprooted his family and walked nearly 2,000 miles on a dangerous trek from Honduras to the United States last spring to escape from a violent gang that was extorting him. The group demanded a monthly payment, he said, to allow him to run his car shop in peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: A Blood Test Predicts Pre-eclampsia in Pregnant Women
description: The assessment is the first advance in diagnosing the deadly condition since it was discovered more than a century ago, experts said.
content: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a blood test that can identify pregnant women who are at imminent risk of developing a severe form of high blood pressure called pre-eclampsia, a leading cause of disability and death among childbearing women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: After a Fall, Venus Williams Is Eliminated on Wimbledon’s First Day
description: Williams, a five-time Wimbledon singles champion, was vying, at 43, to become one of the oldest women to win a main draw singles match at the sport’s oldest Grand Slam event.
content: She walked onto the court late on a gray and chilly afternoon with that rocking gait that has become so familiar to tennis fans over the past 25 years. With her tennis bag on her shoulder, she pulled at the ends of an elastic band to get in some last-minute upper-body stretches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: A Driver’s License for the Internet
description: Age verification laws are changing websites for both children and adults.
content: Like millions of other teenagers, Jack Merrill, an 18-year-old living outside of Chicago, regularly uses the online game platform Roblox. So when it rolled out a new feature — voice chatting with other users — he wanted to try it. But first, he had to pull out his driver’s license.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Ukrainian Writer Victoria Amelina Dies After Kramatorsk Strike
description: The 37-year-old poet and novelist became the 13th person to be killed in the missile strike on a restaurant in eastern Ukraine on June 27.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Victoria Amelina, one of Ukraine’s best-known young writers, has died from injuries sustained in a Russian missile strike on a crowded restaurant in eastern Ukraine. She was 37.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How to Deal with the Coming Social Security Shortfall
description: Experts disagree on how far we should kick the can down the road.
content: This issue of the newsletter is about cans, roads, kicking and Social Security. Specifically, it’s about how to deal with Social Security’s impending funding shortfall. Is a 20-year fix good enough? How about a 75-year fix? Or how about a fix that — according to today’s best estimates — will last forever?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: G.O.P. Threatens Spy Agencies’ Surveillance Tool
description: With hard-right Republicans attacking federal law enforcement agencies and unwilling to extend their broad powers, a major warrantless surveillance program targeting foreigners overseas may face new limits from Congress.
content: An intensive drive by right-wing Republicans in Congress to vilify the F.B.I. with charges of political bias has imperiled a program allowing spy agencies to conduct warrantless surveillance on foreign targets, sapping support for a premier intelligence tool and amplifying demands for stricter limits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margalit Fox
title: Dr. Susan Love, Surgeon and Breast Health Advocate, Dies at 75
description: One of the world’s most visible public faces in the war on breast cancer, she helped reshape both the doctor’s role and the patient’s.
content: Dr. Susan Love, a surgeon, author, researcher and activist who was for decades one of the world’s most visible public faces in the war on breast cancer, died on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Republicans Have to Sign a Loyalty Pledge to Debate. Who Will and Who Won’t?
description: Donald J. Trump and Ron DeSantis have not given straight answers on whether they will sign the pledge, which is required to make the debate stage.
content: To participate in the first Republican presidential debate on Aug. 23, candidates must meet challenging new criteria, including having at least 40,000 donors and voter support of at least 1 percent in three approved polls. But the requirement causing the most consternation is a pledge to support the eventual nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Israel’s Assault on Jenin
description: Also, the U.S. Treasury Secretary will visit Beijing.
content: Israel launched the most intense airstrikes on the occupied West Bank in nearly two decades and sent hundreds of ground troops into the crowded Jenin refugee camp, saying it was trying to root out armed militants after a year of escalating violence there. At least eight Palestinians were killed, according to the Palestinian health ministry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Canada Offers Lesson in the Economic Toll of Climate Change
description: Wildfires are hurting many industries and could strain households across Canada, one of many countries reckoning with the impact of extreme weather.
content: Canada’s wildfires have burned 20 million acres, blanketed Canadian and U.S. cities with smoke and raised health concerns on both sides of the border, with no end in sight. The toll on the Canadian economy is only beginning to sink in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Prue Leith
title: Prue Leith’s Great American Road Trip
description: The “Great British Baking Show” judge steps out of the tent to sample the flavors of the U.S. on a 2,200-mile drive.
content: ​​Last fall, my husband and I set our hearts on renting an R.V. for a road trip from Los Angeles to Florida. We imagined picnicking on mountaintops in New Mexico, sleeping under the stars in Texas and barbecuing prawns (the R.V. would come with a grill, of course) on a Mississippi levee. In the end, our 2,200-mile American journey ended up being memorable, but for none of those reasons.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Urban Explorers,’ or Russian Agents?
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 3, 2023.
content: “People don’t think about Russians as victims of this government, but we are. Everyone is watching you. Everyone looks at you suspiciously.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: Fourth of July Fireworks and ‘Moonshine’
description: Networks air specials for Independence Day, and the CW premieres a Canadian comedy about a dysfunctional family running a summer resort.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 3-9. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: GOATs Are Everywhere in Sports. So What Really Defines Greatness?
description: Athletes from Tom Brady to Serena Williams to LeBron James have all been tabbed the Greatest of All Time. Faced with the term’s pervasive use, our columnist considers how sports heroes become transcendent.
content: If you are reading this column, I have great news: You’re the GOAT!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Morgan Wallen Tops the Album Chart for a 15th Time
description: Young Thug opens at No. 2 and Peso Pluma at No. 3 as the country superstar continues to dominate the Billboard 200.
content: A month ago, the country superstar Morgan Wallen seemed sidelined. A vocal cord injury had benched him from his arena and stadium tour, and after a 12-week perch atop the Billboard album chart he had ceded No. 1 to Taylor Swift and the K-pop group Stray Kids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Saudi Arabia and Russia to Extend Oil Cuts
description: The major exporters announced supply cuts amid concerns about weaker demand’s effects on prices.
content: Saudi Arabia said Monday that it would extend a cut in oil production of one million barrels a day that it announced in June through at least August, trying to push up what officials view as stubbornly weak oil prices. The Saudis were joined by Russia, whose deputy prime minister Alexander Novak said Moscow would cut supplies by 500,000 barrels in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 6 Podcasts to Help You Take an Actual Break This Summer
description: These shows offer emotional escape with explorations of mysterious cultural moments, soothing soundscapes and stories about petty interpersonal drama.
content: Whatever fantasies you have of a blissfully relaxed summer, the reality often fails to measure up. Many workers can’t (or won’t) take enough time off; parents need to find ways to keep their children occupied once school’s out, and summer travel sometimes comes with enough stressors to cancel out any chill factor. But even if you find yourself in less-than-zen circumstances, you can still choose to slow down and give yourself a mental break this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Jane Stockdale
title: Ben and Bryan Shelton, Son and Father, Hit the Road as Player and Coach
description: Bryan Shelton guided his son for years as a junior and in college. Now he is taking the reins on the ATP Tour. Next up: Wimbledon.
content: Last year, when Ben Shelton decided to leave college and turn professional, he wondered aloud to his father, Bryan, a former player on the men’s tennis tour, if they ought to embark on a venture together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: America’s Foes Are Joining Forces
description: Under both Donald Trump and President Biden, Washington has helped create the very anti-American partnerships it now bemoans.
content: The Biden administration recently made two grim announcements: Iran is helping to manufacture drones for Russia. China operates a spy base in Cuba.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Who’s Winning the Trump vs. DeSantis Meme Wars?
description: The battle reflects the importance of social media for campaigns, and the growing threat of fake images and videos.
content: The battle reflects the importance of social media for campaigns, and the growing threat of fake images and videos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Arum, Mitchell L. Stevens and Quoctrung Bui
title: For Most College Students, Affirmative Action Was Never Enough
description: The loss of affirmative action is an opportunity to refocus on supporting middle- and lower-tiered colleges.
content: The loss of affirmative action is an opportunity to refocus on supporting middle- and lower-tiered colleges.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our Best Fourth of July Desserts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How Well Do You Know These Books on American Independence?
description: America’s big breakup with Britain back in the 18th century has inspired countless books. Test yourself on five of them with this quick quiz!
content: America’s big breakup with Britain back in the 18th century has inspired countless books. Test yourself on five of them with this quick quiz!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Drones Light Up Sky Over Los Angeles Neighborhood
description: Crowds in Lake View Terrace, a suburb of Los Angeles, watched drones fly into different formations to celebrate Independence Day.
content: Crowds in Lake View Terrace, a suburb of Los Angeles, watched drones fly into different formations to celebrate Independence Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Israeli Military Launches Airstrikes on Jenin Refugee Camp
description: Smoke rose from buildings during an Israeli raid in a densely populated area of the occupied West Bank.
content: Smoke rose from buildings during an Israeli raid in a densely populated area of the occupied West Bank.
source.name: The New York Times
